title: As Coronavirus Spreads, U.S. Looks to New Tools to Fight Fallout
summary: Trump invokes Defense Production Act, Senate passes relief bill as confirmed cases surpass 200,000 world-wide; stock market plummets. The U.S. escalated its response to the coronavirus pandemic as growing shutdowns increased fears of economic fallout, pushing the stock market to levels not seen since 2017.

title: Staff at Kirkland Facility With Coronavirus Outbreak Spread It to Other Facilities, Study Finds
summary: Poor procedures fueled the explosive outbreak of the new coronavirus at nine Seattle-area nursing homes. Poor infection-control procedures, irregular supplies of protective equipment, and staff who worked despite feeling sick are among the factors that fueled an explosive outbreak of the new coronavirus at nine Seattle-area nursing homes, according to a new study published Wednesday.

title: Small Businesses Slow Down, Sending Fintech Into a Tailspin
summary: Square, PayPal and other companies that process payments, make loans are bracing for a slowdown as coronavirus keeps consumers from bars, restaurants and beauty salons. Coronavirus is causing big pains for companies that cater to small businesses.

title: Harley Faces Proxy Fight as Shareholder Nominates Two Candidates to Board
summary: Impala Asset Management says ex-CEO Matt Levatich was fired; Harley disputes that. A Harley-Davidson Inc. shareholder nominated two candidates to sit on the motorcycle manufacturer's board, a move that comes as the company is searching for a new chief executive to reinvigorate sales.

title: The Economic Rout Accelerates
summary: The Fed and Treasury need to liquify business now or liquidate later.. You know you have a big economic problem when you roll out your grand solution and markets tank another 6%. That was the sorry story Wednesday, as the Trump Treasury disclosed its $1 trillion proposal to rescue the pandemic economy, and the panic accelerated.

title: The Gig Economy to the Rescue
summary: The flexibility of app services is helping millions in the panic.. Americans have been urged to "social distance" and those who may have been exposed to the coronavirus to self-quarantine. A decade ago this would have been unpleasant but also impractical for most people. Fortunately, there's now an app, or many, many apps, for that.

title: The 'Voter Suppression' Smear Is Back
summary: Local Democratic Party officials are to blame for long waits in recent primaries.. Democrats have accused Republican officials of closing voting locations and rationing voting machines, forcing primary voters to wait hours to vote. This is a distortion of the truth, but it fits the narrative that the GOP will do anything to stop racial minorities from voting. Expect to hear it again and again this election.

title: Parents Choose in Florida
summary: The state tries to meet rising demand for its school-choice programs.. The best defense of school-choice programs is that parents keep choosing them, and Florida is proving the point. A year after setting up a new school-voucher program, state lawmakers passed a bill last week to expand it. Eight House Democrats joined Republicans in favor last Monday, and the Senate voted Friday along party lines to send it to the Governor's desk.

title: The SEC Wants to Be Your Nanny
summary: A proposed rule would limit investments in risky funds to those with 'financial sophistication,' putting middle-class investors at a disadvantage.. Massachusetts once barred its residents from investing in the initial public offering of Apple . As the Journal reported on Dec. 12, 1980, state regulators declared the stock "too risky" for individual investors because its relatively high price-earnings ratio made it a "highflier" that lacked "solid earnings foundations."

title: Gov. Cuomo Orders New York Businesses to Keep Half Their Workforce at Home
summary: Grocery stores, pharmacies, shipping companies, other essential services would be exempt from rule. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo tightened restrictions on businesses Wednesday, telling them to allow employees to telecommute or otherwise keep half their workforce home at any one time, as governors across the tri-state area grappled with increased coronavirus cases.

title: American Travelers Are Trapped Abroad by Coronavirus Lockdowns
summary: As the virus spreads, Americans from Cambodia to Morocco, Chile to Spain are stuck far from home as governments seal borders to try to contain it. LIMA, Peru-It was supposed to have been what the American family called "a bucket list" trip for Lesley Bravi, 77, whose husband had died last year: A trip to Peru with relatives to see the 15th-century Inca citadel of Machu Picchu and Lake Titicaca.

title: With Revenue Forecasts Dim, a Tax Increase Is on the Table in New York
summary: The potential for higher unemployment due to the coronavirus crisis is helping to make the case. ALBANY, N.Y.-The new coronavirus has upended New York state's normal methods of making laws and passing the state budget, and it has given new life to the argument that the state needs to raise taxes.

title: Yes, Flatten the Curve
summary: While medicine fights the coronavirus, the response from Washington to Wall Street looks like the madness of crowds.. Out of every major crisis comes a saying. After the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001-now 9/11-it was "This changes everything." During World War II the British said, "Keep Calm and Carry On"-good advice then and now. For the coronavirus pandemic of 2020, it looks like America's version will be "Flatten the curve."

title: 'The Adventurer's Son' Review: Exploring the Grief
summary: Roman Dial confronts the guilt he feels for having inadvertently set up his son, a fellow adventurer, for an early death.. There's a good reason, quite beyond thrilling accounts of mountains climbed or lost cities discovered, that adventure books have endured as one of nonfiction's most popular genres. The best adventure writers are seekers, traversing not only physical terrain but their emotional depths. Wilfred Thesiger or Cheryl Strayed may be more obsessed than the rest of us, but what they are running away from, what they hope to prove to themselves on dangerous treks, reminds us of our own foibles and how difficult it can be to escape them.

title: Make America Fun Again: Pass a Summer Stimulus Now
summary: Send every U.S. household a $500 prepaid debit card to spend later this year in the 'experience economy.'. Harvard political scientist Robert Putnam argued in "Bowling Alone" (2000) that Americans were spending less time together. Today, Americans aren't merely alone-they're not even bowling. Sports, theaters and restaurants are shut down, and the coronavirus is scaring off frequent flyers. This makes for prudent health policy and a brutal business environment.

title: U.S. Suspending Routine Visas in Most Countries in Response to Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Suspension applies to all routine immigrant and nonimmigrant visas. WASHINGTON-The State Department said Wednesday that it is suspending routine visa services in most countries world-wide in response to the outbreak of the new coronavirus.

title: Some Bank Branches Run Low on Cash as Customers Make Big Withdrawals
summary: Regulators stress risks of keeping large sums of cash at home rather than in an insured institution. WASHINGTON-Some branches of U.S. banks and credit unions have run low on cash as customers make big withdrawals, prompting regulators to warn that they are putting their money at risk.

title: Trudeau Turns Trumpian, Temporarily
summary: The U.S.-Canada border is closed by 'mutual consent.'. Toronto

title: Mexico Slow to Implement Strong Measures Against Coronavirus
summary: President cites impact on economy; other Latin American nations, with fewer cases, have taken tougher actions. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's government is resisting implementing strong measures to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, even as President Trump said Wednesday that he would block the entry of asylum seekers and ban nonessential travel across the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: Israel's Parliament Adjourned in Clash Over Powers
summary: Move blocks opposition effort to oversee Netanyahu's response to coronavirus. TEL AVIV-The speaker of Israel's parliament, an ally of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, abruptly adjourned the body, blocking an opposition effort to place his aggressive response to the coronavirus under legislative oversight.

title: Square Gets Green Light to Open a Bank
summary: Financial-tech company began its bid for a bank for 2½ years ago. Federal and state banking regulators approved an application from financial-tech company Square Inc. to start its own bank in Utah.

title: NYSE to Close Trading Floor After Two Positive Coronavirus Tests
summary: Investors will likely see little impact to markets as exchange will shift to all-electronic trading. The New York Stock Exchange will close its famed trading floor in lower Manhattan effective Monday after two people who work at the exchange tested positive for coronavirus.

title: New York City Had a Coronavirus Warning Sign: Spikes in ER Visits
summary: The visits increased daily beginning on March 1, and various factors could have contributed to the rise. New York City hospital emergency rooms started seeing a sharp rise in people coming in with flulike symptoms in early March-a concerning signal well before the crisis ramped up.

title: Purdue Bankruptcy Shield Extended to Sacklers Through October
summary: Some states had sought to resume lawsuits against the Sackler family despite bankruptcy negotiations surrounding its drugmaker, Purdue Pharma. The judge overseeing Purdue Pharma LP's bankruptcy shielded the OxyContin maker's owners for another six months from lawsuits over the U.S. opioid crisis, saying that forcing them to defend themselves would disrupt settlement talks.

title: Coronavirus Triggers Wave of U.S. Workers Filing for Jobless Benefits
summary: Some states see unprecedented application volumes-Ohio gets 78,000 claims in three days, up from about 3,000 in prior-week period; states shift staff to handle surge. The new coronavirus pandemic has triggered a wave of U.S. workers filing for state jobless benefits, with states across the nation receiving a sharp rise in applications as businesses shut down and out-of-work Americans hunt for a payment lifeline.

title: Many Democratic Media Myths Remain True
summary: Joe Biden and Sen. Bernie Sanders agree far more than they disagree.. Reading between the lines of Rahm Emanuel's "Democratic Voters Smash Media Myths" (op-ed, March 13), one gets the impression that he doesn't trust the media to be objective. His suggestion that journalists have an ax to grind and are obsessed with identity politics, money in politics and the desirability of Scandinavian-style socialism sounds a lot like the complaints of conservatives who are deemed right-wing loonies.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic to Test Limits of How Much Debt U.S. Can Bear
summary: Federal Reserve has capacity to buy massive amount of bonds if investors balk. The coronavirus pandemic is about to test the bounds of how much debt the U.S. government can bear.

title: Bringing Big-City Culture to a Wider Public
summary: New York's rich cultural offerings are unavailable to live audiences elsewhere. But this creates an opportunity for Broadway houses to dive into the online audience market that already exists.. Regarding Terry Teachout's "How the Show Can Go On" (Sightings, March 13): No new venture can be so well planned that every risk is avoided. My wife and I hope Broadway producers will embrace this philosophy and follow Terry Teachout's recommendation that New York City theaters consider live streaming their performances.

title: Convenient to Vote In California, but Better?
summary: Many people who voted early were disenfranchised because they wound up voting for candidates who had withdrawn by election day.. Regarding the letters of March 13 responding to your editorial "California Steals Its Own Election" (March 7): Those who waited until the last minute to vote, on what is supposed to be Election Day, had the latest information regarding candidates who had dropped out of the running, making their vote more relevant than those who voted earlier. For example, many people who voted early were disenfranchised because they wound up voting for candidates who had withdrawn by Election Day.

title: No Easy Answers to Coronavirus Disruptions
summary: Economic development is tied to health outcomes, and a recession usually leads to adverse health consequences.. The heartbreaking "It May Not Be the Virus That Kills Me" (op-ed, March 13) by Prof. Mark C. Taylor is an illustration of the delicate balance that the war on the coronavirus must strike. The calls for closing down the economy to prevent the spread of the virus may not only send millions to the unemployment line and crush businesses, but may have huge health consequences. The direct consequences are in the article, and I wish Mr. Taylor the very best. However, economic development is tied to health outcomes, and a recession usually leads to adverse health consequences (as evidenced in research on the "2007-09 recession"). There are indirect costs as well, as people lose health insurance and the investment in research and in lifesaving technology declines. Six hundred thousand people died of cancer in the U.S. in 2017.

title: Airline, Hotel Shares Plunge on Disappointing Rescue Plan
summary: Government offers loans, rather than direct cash infusion companies had sought. Airline shares fell sharply Wednesday after the Trump Administration proposed providing assistance to the struggling industry in loans, rather than the direct cash infusion companies had requested.

title: Yes, the Fed Is Serving, but Who Bellies Up to the Bar?
summary: The Federal Reserve is making capital and liquidity extraordinarily available in this apprehensive economic environment.. The Federal Reserve is making capital and liquidity extraordinarily available in this apprehensive economic environment ("The Fed Returns to 2008," Review & Outlook, March 16). Somehow this seems akin to a bar offering deep discounts to teetotalers.

title: Treasury Asks Congress to Let It Backstop Money Markets
summary: Officials want to relieve strains in a market seen as a safe place to park cash temporarily. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is asking Congress for authority to develop guarantee programs for the $4 trillion money-market mutual-fund industry, as part of its broader effort to calm turmoil sparked by the novel coronavirus epidemic.

title: Sanders Weighs His Future After Losses to Biden
summary: Campaign manager says Vermont senator 'is going to be having conversations with supporters to assess his campaign' after Tuesday's primaries. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders is weighing the future of his campaign after a third consecutive string of losses to former Vice President Joe Biden in the Democratic presidential race.

title: IRS Details Tax-Payment Deadline Deferral to July 15 Due to Coronavirus
summary: Government to waive interest, penalties for 2019 filers, 2020 estimated taxes. WASHINGTON-The Internal Revenue Service began providing details for taxpayers to defer their April 15 payments to July 15, offering relief to people who owe income taxes for 2019 or estimated income taxes for the first quarter of 2020.

title: Boards Begin Planning for Long-Term Fallout From Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Thirteen percent of directors say their companies have delayed planned investments for 2020, according to the National Association of Corporate Directors. Corporate directors, after spending weeks in crisis mode, have begun to plan for the long-term fallout from the coronavirus pandemic on their operations.

title: Tennis Groups Suspend Events Until June
summary: Coronavirus prompts action by the Association of Tennis Professionals and Women's Tennis Association. The Association of Tennis Professionals and the Women's Tennis Association issued a joint statement suspending all tournaments until June 7 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Military to Deploy Two Hospital Ships to Help Slow Coronavirus
summary: Both vessels first must finish undergoing maintenance and staff preparation, Pentagon says. The U.S. military is planning to deploy its two hospital ships to aid in the country's coronavirus emergency, the Pentagon said Wednesday, but both vessels first must finish undergoing maintenance and staff preparation.

title: Markets Enter New Phase-Where Cash Is All That Matters
summary: Investors sold nearly everything they could Wednesday. A rush for cash shook the financial system Wednesday, as companies and investors hunkered down for a prolonged economic stall, taking the recent market turmoil into a new, more troubling liquidation phase.

title: Fannie, Freddie Suspend Mortgage Foreclosures for 60 Days
summary: The mortgage giants guarantee roughly half of the U.S. housing market. WASHINGTON-Mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are suspending foreclosures and evictions of homeowners behind on their mortgages-and at risk of losing their homes-in the latest federal response to the outbreak of the coronavirus.

title: General Mills Says Demand Rises as Consumers Stockpile
summary: On the down side, its Häagen-Dazs shops and restaurant business face challenges as people stay at home. General Mills Inc. said its cereal, soup and other foods are in high demand as consumers stock up to ride out the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Sheriff Quashes Elon Musk's Aim to Keep Tesla Production Humming
summary: Regional authority says electric car maker can maintain only minimum operations at local factory. Tesla Inc. shares plummeted Wednesday after the sheriff's office in the county home to the company's California car factory said the auto maker must halt production, putting a break on CEO Elon Musk's plans to work in spite of statewide efforts to mitigate the effects of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

title: Banks Take Far Less Than Offered in Repo Operations
summary: Little demand for two Fed repos with $500 billion caps. Two market interventions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Wednesday saw eligible banks borrow far less money than the central bank was willing to offer.

title: A Taxi Driver Steers Through Streets Silenced by Coronavirus
summary: Cabbie Zafer Sari drinks tea with his cohort during Istanbul's typically peak-traffic time; offers cologne as sanitizer, lets passengers use front seat. ISTANBUL-On a typical workday, Zafer Sari had his pick of riders for the passenger seat of his Fiat taxi. At 11 a.m. on Monday, he was drinking tea with fellow drivers at a small cab stand on the European side of Istanbul.

title: 'Saint Cloud' by Waxahatchee Review: Genuine Hope Balanced With Clear-Eyed Realism
summary: A loose, rootsy and countrified album deals with transformation and sobriety in an oblique yet affecting manner..

title: New York Performers Improvise as Coronavirus Keeps Crowds Away
summary: Some artists are turning to online platforms to share their work-in many cases at no cost. When Dani Zoldan realized he would have to close his Stand Up NY comedy club because of the coronavirus pandemic, he figured New Yorkers still needed a laugh-perhaps more than ever.

title: Chinese Doctors and Supplies Arrive in Italy
summary: Beijing dispatches intensive-care personnel to Europe, expressing solidarity and a bid to rebrand. A group of 300 Chinese intensive-care doctors began to arrive in Italy on Wednesday, one of several Chinese offers to support epidemic-stricken European countries, as China tries to rebrand itself internationally from source of the new coronavirus to a friendly helper.

title: William Weld Ends 2020 Republican Presidential Bid
summary: In primaries a day earlier in Florida and Illinois, Mr. Trump collected the delegates needed to capture the GOP's 2020 nomination. WASHINGTON-Former Massachusetts Gov. William Weld ended his long-shot challenge to President Trump for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Stocks, Oil and Bonds Drop in Sync as Economic Fears Deepen
summary: Dow falls 6.3%; oil hits lowest level in more than 18 years amid rising anxiety. Stocks, bonds and commodities fell Wednesday in a simultaneous selloff as investors scrambled to raise cash to buffet themselves against the widening economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pressure From Athletes to Delay Olympics Intensifies
summary: Though the IOC has repeatedly insisted that the Tokyo Games would go ahead as planned, the organization is now facing loud criticism from its own constituents. Opposition to holding the Olympics on schedule this July spiked to new levels on Wednesday among the people with some of the loudest voices in sports: members of the International Olympic Committee and the athletes themselves.

title: For These Former Athletes, Real Estate Is a Whole New Ballgame
summary: A professional golfer and a major league baseball player discuss their foray into selling property. Chuck Cary

title: Strong Restaurant Chains May Feast After Coronavirus Famine
summary: Coronavirus pandemic will devastate the U.S. restaurant sector, but financially stronger companies should expect a return to growth in a less-saturated market. For America's restaurant business, overwhelming darkness today might well lead to a brighter future.

title: As Workplaces Empty, Some Holdouts Have Wanted Staff to Show Up
summary: Managers have argued risks are overstated as staff push for flexible work arrangements amid pandemic. Some businesses for days played down the health threat of the new coronavirus or directed employees to continue coming into offices as federal and local health authorities have called for flexible work arrangements to slow the spread of the disease.

title: Consumer-Staples Shares Outperform Market as Households Hunker Down
summary: Investors are anticipating the needs of the stay-at-home consumer. Investors are anticipating the needs of the stay-at-home consumer.

title: Turmoil in Funding Markets Drags Down Mortgage REITs
summary: Used of borrowed money amplifies declines. Shares of mortgage real-estate investment trusts declined sharply Wednesday, reflecting growing concerns about firms that use borrowed money to juice returns at a time when funding markets are in turmoil.

title: Trump Sought to Expand Virus Drug Tests Over FDA Objections
summary: Plan would have expanded use of investigational drugs for coronavirus; FDA officials said plan would pose risks to patients. WASHINGTON-The White House considered issuing an executive order greatly expanding the use of investigational drugs against the new coronavirus, but met with objections from Food and Drug Administration scientists who warned it could pose unneeded risks to patients, according to a senior government official.

title: Emerging Markets Take Hit as Investors Flee for Safety
summary: Resume Subscription. The widespread selloff triggered by the coronavirus pandemic is ripping through emerging markets, as investors suck money out of riskier corners of the globe.

title: Call It a Layoff, a Furlough or a Cut Shift: Americans are Losing Work
summary: Many employers are cutting staff or reducing hours; 'It's kind of a demoralizing thing'. Employers are cutting shifts, suspending work and starting to lay off workers as the new coronavirus devastates business across the country.

title: Bernie Sanders's Revolution Has a Math Problem
summary: The Vermont senator would need to win roughly 63% of the remaining unallocated Democratic delegates to win the presidential nomination. The political revolution Bernie Sanders hoped would sweep him into the White House has run into the cold, hard realities of math: He needs to win roughly 63% of the remaining unallocated Democratic delegates to overtake Joe Biden and win the presidential nomination.

title: What We Miss When Broadway Goes Dark
summary: Art can provide escapism and spiritual sustenance, and other thoughts on what masterpieces say in a time of social distancing..

title: Only Congress Could Change Date of November Election
summary: Primaries are one thing, but the first Tuesday after Nov. 1 is enshrined in law. WASHINGTON-The increasingly strict public-health measures designed to slow the spread of coronavirus are raising concerns about the feasibility of holding the remaining Democratic presidential primary contests, as well as the logistics of holding a November general election if the pandemic is still under way.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Plunge to Lowest Level in 18 Years
summary: Tighter travel restrictions, Saudi-Russian price war drive WTI to its lowest level since 2002. U.S. crude prices plunged to their lowest levels in 18 years on Wednesday, as governments tightened travel restrictions across the world and the continuing Saudi-Russian price war showed no signs of abating.

title: Oil, Mining Companies Voice Opposition to Proposed Disclosure Rule
summary: Some multinationals have joined anti-corruption advocates to call for regulatory alignment with regimes in Europe and Canada regarding disclosure of payments to foreign governments. A proposed rule mandating the disclosure of payments made by oil, gas and mining companies to foreign governments has become the target of anti-corruption advocates and even some businesses who say it fails to align with international standards.

title: The Government Wants to Send You Money-but How Soon Will It Arrive?
summary: Lawmakers face a tradeoff between speed and accuracy as they try to fill holes in household budgets. WASHINGTON-Getting lump-sum payments into the hands of every American could take weeks to start and months to complete as the government tries to turn its tax-collection system into a money-distribution machine.

title: Census Bureau Suspends 2020 Census Field Work
summary: Some in-person delivery of census forms delayed, but households can respond online, by phone or mail. WASHINGTON-The Census Bureau is suspending field work on the 2020 census until April 1 to protect thousands of census workers and help slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, the agency said Wednesday.

title: Gasoline Is Cheap. Americans Can't Take Advantage.
summary: Inexpensive gasoline normally boosts the economy, but that benefit likely won't be realized because of the pandemic. Under normal circumstances, the recent fall in gas prices would make Sharon Sykes happy. But she isn't driving much these days.

title: Trump Spurns Business Plea to Ease Tariffs
summary: Industry groups press for action to stimulate U.S. economy. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is brushing aside calls to put broad import tariffs on hold, despite pleas from the business community that it could stimulate the increasingly rocky U.S. economy.

title: Coronavirus Is Spreading at Religious Gatherings, Ricocheting Across Nations
summary: From Malaysia to Iran, faith groups and pilgrims have emerged as risks, transmitting the disease in ways that are proving difficult to trace and contain. Malaysia has closed schools, offices and places of worship as the country tries to contain an outbreak of coronavirus infections linked to an Islamic religious gathering. Attendees of the event have also taken cases of the virus to Singapore and Brunei.

title: Grocery Delivery Strains to Meet Voracious Demand
summary: Customers preparing for long stretches at home wait days for their online orders. Grocers aren't meeting the now-intense demand for their delivery services, as consumers endure cancellations and long waits on orders they are placing to prepare for long stretches at home.

title: New York City Weighs Turning Hotels Into Hospitals
summary: Hotels could be used for patients without the coronavirus, city's emergency management commissioner says. New York City is working with the hospitality industry to possibly convert entire hotels into hospitals for patients without the novel coronavirus, in an effort to increase capacity at medical facilities as the outbreak grows.

title: Co-Founder of AutoZone Enlivened a Dreary Branch of Retailing
summary: Peter Formanek helped create brightly lighted stores and held down costs by staying in cheap motels. Buying parts for your car in the 1970s typically meant asking a guy, slouched behind a grubby counter with a cigarette or toothpick in his teeth, to fetch a spark plug or wiper blade.

title: Canada Rolls Out Fiscal Boost and Tax Deferrals for Coronavirus Relief
summary: The measures amount to nearly 4% of GDP and would be targeted at people unable to earn income. OTTAWA-Canada announced a fiscal-stimulus and tax-deferral package amounting to nearly 4% of its gross domestic product, marking an aggressive effort to contain economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic and lower oil prices.

title: Skype Brilliantly in These Optimistically Hued Suits
summary: Tailoring in unexpected colors including crimson and clover is increasingly popular in menswear circles-and just the thing to brighten up video-based conferencing. THE SUITS offered by Paris label Berluti this spring come in hunger-inducing hues like mustard yellow, tomato-sauce red and eggplant purple-shades more typically found at the supermarket than in Saks's tailoring department. Yet unexpected colors punctuate much of the suiting this season. Alexander McQueen wants you to contemplate a flamboyant flamingo-pink version; Marni's spin is Caribbean turquoise; and French label Jacquemus sells a lime-green set that recalls a Sierra Mist can.

title: Fried-Brain Fridays: The Journal's Contest Crosswords and Their Die-Hard Solvers
summary: Meet the Muggles, who regularly decipher how Vanna White, Oscar envelopes and the letters ROY G BIV lead to that elusive contest mug. This article discusses three contest crosswords that have been published in The Wall Street Journal over the past several years. If you'd like to try solving these before reading further, they are, from easiest to toughest, here, here, and here:

title: Quake Rocks Utah During Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: Airport shut down, Mormon temple damaged, but no serious injuries reported. An earthquake shook Utah awake Wednesday morning, knocking out power and damaging infrastructure while the state was already hunkered down to slow the spread of coronavirus.

title: Biden Wins, but Sanders Persuades
summary: Dan Lipinski's loss Tuesday is a metaphor for the whole party.. Another sign of the age: Chicagoland Congressman Dan Lipinski, one of the Democratic Party's final antiabortion holdouts, lost a primary election Tuesday by two points, or about 2,500 votes. The traditional working-class Democrats who once chose Mr. Lipinski-and his father before him-used to be a keystone in the party's base.

title: U.S. Spending on Ride-Hailing With Uber, Lyft Falls as Coronavirus Spreads
summary: Americans spent 21% less on Uber rides in the week ending March 16 compared with the previous week.

title: British Pound Falls to Lowest Level Since 1985
summary: Decline in sterling comes as investors favor safer assets such as the U.S. dollar. The British pound fell to its lowest level against the dollar in 35 years, a reflection of the U.K. economy's unique exposure to the disruptions ripping through the global economy because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Bridgewater Associates Performance Hit by Coronavirus
summary: The world's largest hedge-fund firm took a big hit to its funds as it got caught out by the market impact of the coronavirus. Bridgewater Associates LP, the world's largest hedge-fund firm, took a big hit to its funds as it got caught out by the market impact of the coronavirus.

title: Hospitals Are Running Out of Masks, Other Key Equipment
summary: Some hospitals go the DIY route, while doctors and nurses clean and stretch out single-use gear. 'This is battlefield medicine.'. Hospitals across the U.S. are running out of the masks, gowns and other equipment they need to protect staff against the novel coronavirus as they struggle to take care of patients, say hospital officials, doctors and others in the industry.

title: Ride-Sharing Gets Locked Down by Coronavirus
summary: Coronavirus restrictions will cost Uber and Lyft and likely sideline their road to profitability. For a sign of how the coronavirus is hurting the ride-sharing business, consider this: It took a global pandemic to make Uber Technologies ' food-delivery business look appetizing.

title: Stay-at-Home Moms Are Ready for Covid-19
summary: I'm already used to telecommuting while tending to the needs of my 4-year-old son.. An email from my editor popped into my inbox: "Can you edit this story? We would like to use it for tomorrow's paper." Just then I was setting up the Black & Decker toy tool kit that I had promised my son, then 2, weeks earlier as a reward for doing such a great job with potty training. The timing was tough-toddlers and newspaper editors both have immediate deadlines, and both can be impatient to get what they want.

title: Tuesday's Vote Shows Older and Moderate Democrats Drive Primaries
summary: Traditional Joe Biden coalition surges, giving former vice president a big advantage over Bernie Sanders. WASHINGTON-Sen. Bernie Sanders's sweeping losses in three states on Tuesday provide more evidence that the energy in the Democratic Party is with its moderate voters and seniors, not the young and the most liberal.

title: Cannes Lions Ad Festival Postponed to October
summary: The ad industry's biggest annual gathering gives up on June dates. Ascential PLC postponed the annual Cannes Lions advertising festival in France to October, acknowledging that global efforts to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus had made the original June dates untenable.

title: Russia Cements Ties With Crimea, Freezing Conflict With West
summary: Six years after Russia seized Crimea from Ukraine, the peninsula is tightly bound to Moscow, which now covers almost 70% of the territory's budget.

title: Apple Updates iPad, MacBook Air With New Keyboard
summary: Tech giant drops price on MacBook Air by $100 as it abandons troublesome butterfly keyboard. Apple Inc. on Wednesday introduced a new keyboard for an upgraded MacBook Air, another sign that it is abandoning the problematic butterfly keyboard it introduced in 2015 that required extended repair programs.

title: Beijing Escalates the New Cold War
summary: Expelling U.S. reporters will solidify the bipartisan consensus that Communist China is a hostile threat.. While the coronavirus pandemic dominates headlines, an even more consequential crisis is unfolding under the shadow of its wings. That is the upheaval of the relationship between the U.S. and China, a pillar of the economic and political world order since the end of the Cold War. The pandemic will pass; the crises in Sino-American relations could be felt for decades.

title: Trump's Tariffs Leave the U.S. Short on Vital Medical Supplies
summary: From gloves to respirators, protectionism is raising costs for the providers fighting the coronavirus.. Why would the U.S. increase the cost and difficulty of supplying protective gear to doctors and nurses? Why would Washington obstruct the acquisition of lifesaving equipment? Because the sclerosis of trade protectionism, once it takes hold, constricts economic health and adaptation.

title: Long-Duration Bond Funds Thrive Amid Market Carnage
summary: Funds that invest in debt with average maturities of over 20 years are producing outsize returns. A small group of funds that invest in long-duration bonds, or debt with average maturities of over 20 years-is producing outsize returns amid the market turmoil.

title: Bond Market Cracks Open for Blue-Chip Companies-Then Slams Shut
summary: Companies issued around $28 billion in bonds Tuesday after no deals on Monday. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. bankers were marketing bonds for Verizon Communications Inc. and Exxon Mobil Corp. on Tuesday when investors countered with an offer: If Goldman were interested in raising some cash for itself, they would be interested in buying.

title: Overloaded Storage Likely to Mean Even Lower Oil Prices
summary: A coming surge of Saudi oil could push prices to $10 a barrel or less, say analysts. Storage facilities around the world are brimming with cheap oil and could run out of space within months, traders and analysts say, a predicament that could drive down crude prices to unprecedented single-digit dollar amounts.

title: A Natural Wonder in the Woods Outside Amsterdam
summary: Jeroen van Harten and Sabine Karthaus used funds from the sale of their city triplex to build an environmentally conscious home that generates nearly a third of their electricity needs. After making a killing on an Amsterdam apartment in 2016, Jeroen van Harten and Sabine Karthaus looked beyond the Dutch capital to see what they could find. "It was either the sea or the woods," says Ms. Karthaus, a human-resources executive for a car-leasing company.

title: Top Colleges in the South for Student Outcomes
summary: Duke University is No. 1 for the region in this category of the WSJ/THE College Rankings. The top 10 Southern schools for student outcomes in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings include two that are among the top 10 for outcomes nationwide and four public schools.

title: Game Giant Tencent Is Only Partial Coronavirus Winner
summary: Some tech businesses will benefit from more home-working and home-playing, but others will suffer with the rest of the economy. It is good that Chinese tech giant Tencent Holdings Ltd. sells games when everyone is holed up at home. But social distancing won't be as good for its other businesses.

title: Trump and the Art of the Legislative Deal
summary: Plus, Democratic primary voters once again reject Italian-style health care.. As always, Wall Street and Washington are full of people with intriguing schemes for using massive federal power to address an economic calamity. But of course the best way to address such a calamity is to avoid it.

title: Auto Makers Slow Production as Coronavirus Dents Sales
summary: With Americans staying at home, dealers say new-car sales are tanking in the industry's most lucrative market. The worsening virus outbreak is denting sales and store traffic at U.S. dealerships and leading some car companies to suspend work at North America factories, early indications of the pandemic's impact on the U.S. auto industry.

title: Tom Brady, Tampa Bay Buccaneer? Yo-Ho-Ho
summary: Not long after a legend leaves New England, a Florida destination emerges. First of all, how is everyone?

title: Pakistani Court Hears Appeal of Man Convicted of Killing Journal Reporter
summary: Omar Saeed Sheikh seeks to overturn 2002 conviction and death sentence in murder of Daniel Pearl. KARACHI, Pakistan-A Pakistani court is weighing the appeal of a British national convicted and sentenced to death nearly 18 years ago in the murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl, lawyers involved in the proceedings said.

title: No Lucky Charms, Plenty of Okra-What's Left at the Grocery Store
summary: Coronavirus preppers urgently stock up at the supermarket, leaving shelves bare, except for all those pork rinds. Desperate times call for desperate measures.

title: Short-Term Bond Market Roiled by Panic Selling
summary: Many traders are selling what they can, not what they want to sell. Short-term bonds typically act as a haven in turbulent times. But debt maturing in three years or less has been routed in recent days, punishing investors in markets ranging from corporate bonds to asset-backed debt.

title: Honda Plans to Shut Down North American Plants for Six Days Due to Virus Concerns, Demand Decline
summary: Honda says temporary closures will start Monday, and workers will be paid; cut production by 40,000 vehicles. Honda Motor Co. said Wednesday it will temporarily close about a dozen factories in the U.S., Canada and Mexico for six days to respond to concerns about the rapidly spreading virus and in anticipation of lower consumer demand.

title: China's Expulsion of American Journalists Raises Red Flags Over Hong Kong
summary: Beijing bars expelled journalists from working in Hong Kong, encroaching on the financial hub's right to control its own immigration policy. HONG KONG-The Chinese government's move to ban more than a dozen journalists expelled from the mainland from reporting in Hong Kong heightened concerns about a further erosion of the city's relative autonomy.

title: Health-Care Investor Makes New Bankruptcy Bid for Bay Area Hospital
summary: Failed suitor for Verity Health's Seton Medical Center floats $50 million cash offer, says owner is blocking it from bidding. Health-care company Strategic Global Management Inc. said it would pay $50 million in cash for two bankrupt Bay Area hospitals owned by Verity Health System of California Inc. but is being blocked by the owner from bidding on the properties.

title: Store Shelves Stripped of Laptops as Coronavirus Increases Working From Home
summary: Equipment makers were already grappling with supply-chain bottlenecks before demand in U.S. spiked. Brad Sutton, a pastor and commercial photographer, went shopping for a new laptop Friday after the one he owned died. The model he was looking for was sold out. His backup was also gone, as was a third option recommended by a store employee.

title: Devilish Math Would Bring Market Down Another 40%
summary: Stock market numerology says 1435 is the new 666. Following the September 2008 financial crisis, the market didn't hit its bottom until a few months later, in March 2009. On March 6, the S&P 500 index hit what would be its lowest intraday level: 666 points.

title: China's Coronavirus Response Toughens State Control and Weakens the Private Market
summary: Communist Party leaders leaned hard on state-owned enterprises to fight the virus, hastening a retreat from a market-oriented economy. BEIJING-As China prepared to battle the coronavirus disease, President Xi Jinping ordered state-owned companies to step up "unconditionally, and at any cost," according to officials briefed on the late January directive.

title: Intel to Release Neuromorphic-Computing System
summary: Pohoiki Springs, an experimental system to be rolled out this month, mimics the way human brains work to do computations faster with less energy. Intel Corp. is releasing an experimental research system for neuromorphic computing, a cutting-edge method that simulates the way human brains work to perform computations faster, using significantly less energy.

title: Plunging Rates Spell Opportunity for Student-Loan Borrowers
summary: What you should consider when it comes to student loans, the interest waiver and refinancing. As financial markets grapple with fast-moving developments, including emergency interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and stimulus plans in Washington, borrowers could see interest rates on student loans decline dramatically, likely to record lows.

title: Online Fashion Is a Weak Coronavirus Antidote
summary: Zara's owner Inditex has closed half its stores worldwide. With a recession looming, there are few signs that shoppers will buy online instead.. As the global outbreak of Covid-19 forces fashion chains to shut stores, there are few signs that shoppers will flock to virtual outlets instead.

title: How Tom Brady Wound Up on the Tampa Bay Buccaneers
summary: The star quarterback exits New England after winning six Super Bowl titles and is expected to get a fresh start in Tampa Bay for a season when he'll be 43. Tom Brady will be a Tampa Bay Buccaneer. It's just as strange and shocking as that simple sentence sounds.

title: Biden Sweeps Tuesday's Primaries as Voters Confront Coronavirus Fears
summary: The vice president pads his lead over Bernie Sanders in convention delegates. Joe Biden won all three primaries held Tuesday on a day filled with anxious voting, building a lead in the Democratic presidential nomination race that appears increasingly difficult for Bernie Sanders to overcome.

title: The First Rule of Co-Working With Your Spouse: Don't Yell Out for Toilet Paper
summary: Peloton machines, noise-canceling headphones, shared calendars and not-so-smooth jazz help couples stay sane while working together. Brooke Markevicius was on a Zoom call with a potential business partner last week when the ultimate work-from-home embarrassment happened: Her husband yelled to her for toilet paper.

title: A Day in the Life of Reese Witherspoon's TV Right Hand
summary: Lauren Neustadter is the head of TV and film for Reese Witherspoon's media company Hello Sunshine, which produced the new Hulu show Little Fires Everywhere. For anyone committed to a 9-to-5 schedule, the job of Hollywood producer is something to avoid, at least if Lauren Neustadter's daily routine is anything to go by. As head of film and television for Reese Witherspoon's multimedia company, Hello Sunshine, Neustadter, 40, begins a typical day in December at 4:30 a.m. reading scripts. After dropping off her kids at school, she digs into a packed schedule that doesn't end until 7:30 p.m.-on a good night. But Neustadter doesn't mind the long days. "Getting to tell stories that I'm deeply passionate about," she says, "that's a total dream."

title: Private-Equity Investors Try to Gauge Coronavirus Cash Crunch
summary: Limited partners are hoping the stock-market declines don't keep them from putting more cash into private equity.

title: What Does the Covid-19 Economy Look Like?
summary: Chinese poultry prices are ticking up after a monthslong free fall. Artificial intelligence suggests that could show a broader rebound.. Fear of the novel coronavirus has rocked financial markets and raised the specter of recession, prompting questions about what the economic fallout might look like in China and globally.

title: As Homeowners Wait Out Coronavirus, Some Rush to Refinance
summary: Falling interest rates are causing a flurry of mortgage refinancing applications. What you should know to lock in these new rates.

title: U.S. Power Use Weakening After Plunging in Italy Amid Coronavirus
summary: Power demand in Italy has fallen 18% so far. Experts say such data can be a real-time indicator of coming economic damage.. Demand for electricity is beginning to weaken in parts of the U.S. hardest hit by the coronavirus and could fall further in coming days as shelter-in-place orders spread, following a path taken by Italy's industrial region.

title: A Sadness Machine for a March Without the Madness
summary: The Wall Street Journal's Madness Machine is back to complete your bracket for a season that didn't have an ending. It's become a national custom to spend this week every year being the worst possible employee in the world. You use the office printer to make copies of the NCAA tournament bracket. You research another sleeper every time your boss blinks. By Thursday, you don't even bother coming to work so you can watch the games. And if you're good enough at being a horrible employee, you win the office pool and then everyone pays you even more money.

title: China's Glowing Coronavirus-Response Coverage Triggers Anger at State Media
summary: Furor over government's glorification of Xinhua reporter flares into broader attacks on Communist Party's muzzling of news media. HONG KONG-As China's government promotes its successes in containing the coronavirus to audiences abroad, a heated backlash against a state-media reporter's coverage of the pathogen shows that Beijing still faces a tough task selling its narrative at home.

title: Governments Ask Their Citizens to Come Home
summary: Advisories are sharp departure from the highly globalized habits of business, education and tourism. HONG KONG-With cases of the new coronavirus spreading quickly around the world, a growing number of countries have a simple message for citizens traveling overseas: Come home.

title: The (Mostly) Unintended Consequences of Airline Bailouts
summary: Rescuing carriers is probably a necessary evil, but it will also cement everything investors dislike about European aviation. Even in a crisis that could dwarf 9-11, airline bailouts are a bitter pill for taxpayers to swallow. But they are also depressing for financially robust carriers dreaming of a more profitable European market.

title: Coronavirus Scrambles U.S. Olympic Team Qualifying
summary: Postponed trials and closed training facilities leave athletes wondering how they'll qualify for Team USA. Speculation about whether the Tokyo 2020 Olympics will go off July 24 as planned is quickly giving way to a more pressing question: How would Team USA pick a team to compete there?

title: Photos: Russia Makes Its Mark on Crimea
summary: From new roads and a bridge to an airport and new apartment buildings, the Kremlin has invested large sums in the Crimean Peninsula after annexing it in 2014.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Tech Disruption Can Take Decades-Just Ask Architects
summary: Most Popular News. New technologies are changing the workplace at lightning speed-or so conventional wisdom goes. In practice, digital transformation can be painstakingly slow, often because it takes workers much longer than expected to master new skills. Take the field of architecture.

title: Seattle Shows How Coronavirus Shuts Down a City
summary: As downtown stores close, citizens debate whether and when to leave home; 'I'm going to get my hair cut before they close for two months'. SEATTLE-The buses on Melissa Paulen's commute to work at the University of Washington Medical Center have been nearly empty for almost a week. The halls of the hospital are almost empty as well, as visitors have been tightly restricted, and nonessential staff are working from home.

title: SoftBank Backs Away From Part of Planned WeWork Bailout
summary: Investor told office-sharing company it may not buy $3 billion of shares from existing investors as planned. SoftBank Group Corp. is backing away from part of its planned bailout of WeWork, people familiar with the matter said, privately citing several regulatory investigations of the office-sharing company.

title: China Banishes U.S. Journalists
summary: Beijing takes further measures against Voice of America and Time; Secretary of State Pompeo criticizes action. BEIJING-China said it would revoke the press credentials of Americans working for three major U.S. newspapers in the largest expulsion of foreign journalists in the post-Mao era, amid an escalating battle with the Trump administration over media operating in the two countries.

title: The Top Takeaways From Tuesday's Primaries
summary: Biden continued racking up delegates as Sanders's path narrowed further. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden continued to stitch together a diverse coalition of voters with wins in three large states, heightening his advantage over Sen. Bernie Sanders in what stands to be the final voting until next month.

title: Marie Newman Defeats Rep. Dan Lipinski in Illinois Primary Challenge
summary: Newman's win over the eight-term incumbent ignited the Democratic Party's left flank. Marie Newman beat eight-term incumbent Illinois Rep. Dan Lipinski in the primary on Tuesday, a win that ignited the Democratic Party's left flank on a night when the progressives' preferred candidate failed to regain momentum.

title: Still Traveling in the Middle of Coronavirus
summary: How life has changed for the people still flying-moments of odd quiet, and planes often so empty fliers can still practice social distancing. Frequent fliers quickly became frequent hand-washers. And despite everything, some are still wiping down their tray tables and flying on.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump Administration Seeks to Send Checks to Americans as Part of Stimulus Package
summary: Coronavirus-driven economic slowdown prompts $1 trillion stimulus proposal, including effort to get money into consumers' pockets. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration backed a plan to send checks directly to Americans as part of a $1 trillion stimulus package to help households and businesses, a dramatic step designed to cushion the impact of the sudden economic slowdown triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: UAW, Auto Makers Agree to Partial Plant Shutdowns
summary: Ford temporarily closes Chicago factory for virus-related parts shortage. The United Auto Workers and Detroit car companies reached agreements on coronavirus-mitigation efforts that for now will avoid a two-week shutdown of U.S. factories.

title: Trump Administration May Close U.S. Borders to Unauthorized Foreigners
summary: Asylum seekers would be immediately returned to Mexico under a plan that could take effect in as soon as two days. Because of the coronavirus pandemic, the Trump administration is considering a plan to shut the U.S. border with Mexico and Canada as soon as this week to asylum seekers and other foreigners who don't have permission to enter the country, people familiar with the plan said.

title: Fed to Relaunch Primary Dealer Credit Facility
summary: Crisis-era facility allows large financial institutions access to short-term loans. The Federal Reserve said Tuesday it would relaunch a crisis-era facility that allows large financial institutions access to short-term loans.

title: Fed to Launch Funding Facility Amid Coronavirus Uncertainty
summary: Central bank focuses on dysfunction in $1.1 trillion market for short-term corporate IOUs. The Federal Reserve said it would start making loans to American corporations, relaunching a crisis-era tool to help calm short-term debt markets that have faced intensifying strains in recent days.

title: How to Help Limit the Spread of Coronavirus
summary: Home. The coronavirus is now a pandemic, spreading faster in the U.S. and Europe than in Asia. Several states have already closed schools and some businesses. Wherever your state stands, here's a look at some simple steps individuals can take to reduce their risk of contracting the virus and help prevent spreading it.

title: As U.S. Tries to Slow Virus Impact, Europe Hunkers Down
summary: France's 15-day lockdown takes effect as governments pledge billions to help companies, employees; global death toll surpasses 7,800. Cities, states and Washington sought ways to mitigate the blow of the novel coronavirus as businesses closed, the European Union planned to shut its borders, and fears of a pandemic-induced recession kept markets on edge.

title: New York's MTA Seeks $4 Billion Bailout as Ridership Plummets
summary: Agency's head cites collapse in fare revenue in letter to state's congressional delegation. New York's The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has asked for a federal bailout of $4 billion because of the growing cost of the novel coronavirus.

title: Tom Brady's Two Decades in New England
summary: Brady had a 249-75 record, including the postseason, during his 20 seasons with the Patriots.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Government Personnel Chief Resigns After Six Months
summary: Dale Cabaniss had served for more than 20 years as a senior staff member in the U.S. Senate. WASHINGTON-The director of the government Office of Personnel Management has resigned from the post after six months.

title: Behind the Stimulus Frenzy: the Prospect of Billions of Unpaid Bills
summary: Businesses and households have a similar and pressing problem: The money just isn't coming in, but bills still have to get paid. Behind a flurry of activity in Washington Tuesday was an increasingly urgent problem for a nation grappling with the novel coronavirus pandemic: the growing risk that millions of businesses and households won't be able to pay their everyday bills-rent, payroll, utilities-as business activity grinds to an unprecedented halt.

title: Najafi and Trinity Offer to Buy Tegna
summary: Bid values company at about $4.4 billion, adding to crowded field of suitors. Private-equity firm Najafi Cos. and faith-based broadcaster Trinity Broadcasting Network have offered to buy Tegna Inc. for cash consideration of $20 a share, adding their bid to a crowded field of suitors.

title: Boeing Asks for $60 Billion in Aid for U.S. Aerospace Industry
summary: The Chicago-based giant said late Tuesday it was asking for support from private and public sources. Boeing Co. said it was seeking at least $60 billion to aid the U.S. aerospace industry as the plane maker, its suppliers and airline customers face fallout from the growing coronavirus crisis.

title: Sports Media's New Normal: Reruns, Zany Games, Coronavirus Coverage
summary: ESPN, Fox Sports, the Athletic and others are looking to keep users coming back during a period of significant turmoil. Major sports broadcasters and digital publishers are scrambling to find alternatives to fill the void left by the sudden disappearance of live games due to the coronavirus, opting for a mix of reruns, analysis and coverage of the virus's impact on sports leagues.
